body: just want to confirm: will overlord receive credentials of original client that sent the request to coordinator or that of coordinator's http client (e.g. the credentials used by coordinator to talk to overlord in general ) ?
Tested this on a live cluster and it does fix the problem.
üëç

This is a neat feature but I don't know how much battle testing the etag computation code paths have. Some of the underlying code looks racy in ways that can cause hash computation failures. As such, since this is also a new feature, I suggest making sure the code paths will not touch any new code (or will immediately `return null`) unless this feature is enabled.

The racy part I'm not sure about is that the etag computation uses `ServerSelector`'s `pick()` method, which may have an underlying change in discovery state after the initial server selection. But fixing or changing that is beyond the scope of this PR.
Also please make sure there's a coherent story on what thread is doing computation. It is a notoriously tricky thing to track, and cache populating is actually a very compute intensive operation.

@himanshug It gets the credentials sent by the original client (ProxyServlet copies the original headers in copyRequestHeaders())

Good question. The value for `druid.zk.service.host` is passed directly into the [Curator](https://curator.apache.org/) Ensemble connect string. So whatever kind of string is valid for [FixedEnsembleProvider](https://curator.apache.org/apidocs/org/apache/curator/ensemble/fixed/FixedEnsembleProvider.html) is valid for use in this property. I don't have a great link to docs that explain the connection string handy at the moment.
@drcrallen I'm currently testing the changes on one of our internal clusters and should be able to give you a better response once it is done. I have marked this PR in progress for now.

It's the same format described on https://zookeeper.apache.org/doc/trunk/zookeeperProgrammers.html.

> To create a client session the application code must provide a connection string containing a comma separated list of host:port pairs, each corresponding to a ZooKeeper server (e.g. "127.0.0.1:4545" or "127.0.0.1:3000,127.0.0.1:3001,127.0.0.1:3002"). The ZooKeeper client library will pick an arbitrary server and try to connect to it. If this connection fails, or if the client becomes disconnected from the server for any reason, the client will automatically try the next server in the list, until a connection is (re-)established.
I suggest leaving this issue open until the docs are patched to link to the ZK connection string information.

@JLLNANA  If you use tranquility, you don't need a realtime node.

### Reference
https://github.com/druid-io/tranquility/blob/master/docs/overview.md#druid-setup
```
 To get started with the Druid indexing service, you'll need an Overlord, enough Middle Managers for your realtime workload, and enough historical nodes to receive handoffs.
 You don't need any realtime nodes, since Tranquility uses the indexing service for all of its ingestion needs.
```
I just now met this bug.

I think that the coordination dynamic configuration should have <min,max> for `mergeBytesLimit` and `mergeSegmentsLimit`, so far it seems to me that they represent something like both `min & max`. Ie. I had to slowly decrease `mergeSegmentsLimit` to be ably to merge all historical segments as they were growing in time. And I also had sometimes increase `mergeBytesLimit` due to the error above ^

Also, I believe that `druid.coordinator.merge.on` and `druid.coordinator.period.indexingPeriod` should be dynamic configuration as it happens rather adhoc, based on situation.

@jihoonson I checked the `descriptor.json` in s3 deep storage and there is `ShardSpec=none` so I probably forced it without knowing.

We try to get s3-independent and at the same time leverage `druid.coordinator.merge.on` so I'm thinking about using `tranquility`. Can segments produced by `tranquility` be automatically merged?

@dclim added unit test for early publishing, however that uncovered a bug - https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/5046
I think the PR is ready for review, also if possible please exercise the code on your cluster.
I think it's a good idea. Maybe a new thread like abandonExecutor is needed to avoid interleaving?

I realized IndexTask can call ```IngestSegmentFirehoseFactory.connect()``` before acquiring locks which calls ```SegmentListUsedAction.perform()``` and this should be allowed for automatic search for intervals and shardSpecs. I removed some changes about acquiring locks in SegmentList*Action and changed the title and description of this PR accordingly.

May be a new executor can be used as you suggested or just use a counter to keep track of pushes that is happening currently. Submit task to drop the segments to persistExecutor only when the counter is zero, thus not relying on pushBarrier job submitted to pushExecutor to avoid interleaving.
Probably, new executor approach seems cleaner. I don't have preference of one over another.

Left (start) is inclusive and right (end) is exclusive.

As a point of maintenance, I highly suggest specifying the timezone offsets in all your intervals, otherwise it is hard to keep track of what the client intended.

If you are on the west coast of the US, you are going to get results that vastly differ with a `-07` or `-08` time shift vs a `+0000` or `Z` specification.

It is worth noting that if the standard setup guide is followed then the interval timezone will default to UTC.

Great, thank you! Maybe it will be worth noting this explicitly somewhere in the docs?

Currently our system stores and retrieves all data in UTC always, so it shouldn't be problem. Thanks for the heads up, though :-).
Cool! thanks for the contrib!

Out of curiosity, is there a reason extending the `SQLMetadataConnector` doesn't work? For example: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/extensions-core/postgresql-metadata-storage/src/main/java/io/druid/metadata/storage/postgresql/PostgreSQLConnector.java and https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/extensions-core/mysql-metadata-storage/src/main/java/io/druid/metadata/storage/mysql/MySQLConnector.java

The intention of `SQLMetadataConnector` is to make it so most of the boilerplate is taken care of.
Class `OracleMetadataConnector` extends `SQLMetadataConnector`. I have just used different package in comparison to mysql or postgre extensions.

I'm working on this.

I understand your concerns and totally agree that it would be a nightmare to manage in future, if there is some changes inside metadata core classes.

But the problem I faced, there are some SQL queries inside in SQLMetadata*** classes, which are not supported by oracle. For Example, Oracle does not have datatype `boolean`, need to use either type `NUMBER` with values 1, 0 or type `VARCHAR` with values "true", "false". While creating tables, this problem is overcome by overriding the create table methods inside `OracleMetadataConnector` extending `SQLMetadataConnector`. But when running select or update queries need to change used = true to used = "true" inside where conditions. Another example is oracle does not have mysql like auto increment, instead need to use sequence by explicitly calling sequence.nextval for create statements. For these, all the insert queries that has incremental ids also need to be updated. But all these queries are inside the core methods. These are some of the reasons behind duplicating core codes.

It would have been better if there were some sort of functionality to provide the sql queries to core classes by overriding the core methods just like we have for creating tables inside SQLMetadataConnector. So that main functionality inside core will remain same and It will use the provided SQL queries.
